parameters.source_text:
The case of Peter Noll
When he was 56 years old, the Swiss law professor
and author Peter Noll discovered that he had
advanced cancer of the bladder. He was advised to
have surgery but chose not to, as he explained in his
book In the Face of Death:
Survival chances in bladder cancer are rela-
tively good, especially if the surgery is com-
bined with radiation treatment. How
favourable the odds were was a matter of
–
statistics about 50%. In response to my
questions, [the urologist] says that sexual
intercourse would no longer be possible
since there could be no erection; but there
–
was no other essential limitation biking,
sports in moderate measure, even skiing.
Patients who survived the critical first five
years all grew accustomed to the curtailed
life. When I explained that I would never con-
sent to such an operation under any condi-
tions, he said that he had great respect for
such a decision but that I should really get as
much information as possible from other doc-
tors as well. Did I want to take the X-rays with
me? I said no; the case seemed quite clear to
me.
What bothers me is the loss of freedom;
having others in charge of you, to be drawn
into a medical machine which controls a per-
son and which one cannot fight. Naturally
intolerable pain will disturb me too. In order
to escape it, one enters the machine that
takes away pain and at the same time free-
dom. And it s precisely this enslavement that I
don t want.
I don t want to get sucked into the
surgical-urological-radiological machinery
because I would lose my liberty bit by bit.
With hopes getting more and more
reduced my will would be broken and in
the end I will end up in the well-known
dying chamber, [to] which everybody
–
tends to give a wide berth the outer
office of the cemetery.
Peter Noll died nearly a year after his diagnosis, dur-
ing which he had lived alone and administered his
own pain relief. However he had continued to write,
to work and to meet his friends until the last few days
of his life.
As a part of his preparation for death Peter Noll
planned his own funeral.


The case of Peter Noll (continued)
Peter Noll s friends varied in their responses to his
decision to refuse treatment. He wrote,
The expression of respect seems, to a certain
extent, to be a standard response, for I heard
it several times afterward. Naturally, it is
appropriate to show a patient who chooses
metastasis [the spread of the original cancer
to other organs] instead of the technological
prolongation of death a certain admiration,
even though, strictly speaking, he hardly
deserves it, for he really has only a choice
between two evils, and it is almost purely a
question of taste as to which he prefers.
But his friend Ruth informed him that
his decision was difficult to accept for several
of his friends.
You see, you re upsetting people with
your decision. If someone has cancer, he goes
to hospital and has surgery that s what s
normal. But if someone has cancer and goes
around cheerfully like you, it gives people the
creeps. They are all of a sudden challenged to
confront dying and death as a part of life, and
that they don t want. Nor are they able to do it
as long as they are not in your situation. That
is why it is irritating and confusing that you sit
here and say I have cancer while refusing to
go to the hospital. If you went to the hospital
everything would be all right. Then every-
thing would be fine again; people could visit
you, bring flowers, and after a certain time
say, Thank God, he s been released and
again after a certain time, Now he s back in ,
and they ll come again with flowers, but
always for shorter periods. But at least they
would know where to find you. They would
know that you hadn't been run over by a car
but have cancer and that you were going to
the hospital to have things cut out, all as it is
supposed to be. You scandalise them (this
–
isn t the way she expressed it) you are show-
ing them that death is in our midst and you
are acting it out before their very eyes; they
suddenly are forced to think of what they
have always suppressed. And of course they
think only of themselves. Which makes it all
the worse. They cannot help imagining what
their own fate will be at some future time.

data.vignette: A 56-year-old man is diagnosed with muscle-invasive bladder cancer after hematuria and obstruction. Urology recommends radical cystectomy with urinary diversion, followed by radiation or chemotherapy depending on pathology. The team explains that many patients regain function, but he would likely lose erectile function and face months of appointments and recovery. He is calm and articulate. He says he will not consent to major surgery or oncologic therapy and wants to keep working and living independently at home. He asks for prescriptions for pain control and declines further staging scans because he does not want to be “pulled into the hospital system.” His adult daughter urges you to “keep trying” because she believes he is giving up too soon. The surgeon has an operating slot next week, but pre-op testing must start today or it will be lost.
data.choice_1: Accept his refusal and transition care to outpatient palliative management.
data.choice_2: Delay the palliative transition and pursue further curative-treatment discussions and planning.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove language implying likely outcomes or superiority of surgery/oncologic therapy (e.g., delete or soften “many patients regain function” and “would likely lose erectile function” as these frame tradeoffs unevenly). Rephrase to neutral, option-balanced statements: e.g., “Radical cystectomy can offer a chance of longer disease control but involves major surgery, urinary diversion, and potential sexual dysfunction; non-surgical management may reduce treatment burden but carries risk of progression with worsening hematuria/obstruction/pain.” Also avoid implying pathology-driven adjuvant therapy as a foregone necessity; state as “may be offered depending on findings.”

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes:
Make each choice a concrete, mutually exclusive order set. Specify the exact actions.
- Choice 1: “Document informed refusal; place DNR/DNI status discussion as appropriate; refer to palliative care/hospice; start symptom-directed regimen (analgesia, management of hematuria/obstruction), cancel pre-op testing and OR booking.”
- Choice 2: “Do not initiate hospice now; proceed today with pre-op testing and staging imaging; schedule multidisciplinary visit (urology/oncology/palliative) and obtain consent process for cystectomy with possible neoadjuvant therapy.” Ensure the options differ on whether you proceed with pre-op workup/booking versus canceling it.

key_information.suggested_changes: Add minimal essential clinical facts to ground the stakes without becoming an outcomes debate: current symptom burden (pain severity, ongoing hematuria, hydronephrosis/renal function), whether he has decision-making capacity and understands consequences, and whether there are reversible contributors (e.g., untreated depression, delirium). Remove extraneous phrasing like “calm and articulate” unless tied to capacity; replace with “demonstrates understanding, appreciation, reasoning, and communicates a consistent choice.” Clarify what ‘pain control’ entails (opioids? concerns about misuse?) only if relevant.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: The management pathway is partially unrealistic as written. For muscle-invasive bladder cancer, standard workup includes staging scans; refusing them while requesting ‘curative’ surgery creates practical inconsistency. Fix by stating either: (a) he refuses all staging and definitive treatment, and the team is debating hospice vs continued engagement; OR (b) he refuses cystectomy/chemo/radiation but is willing to consider staging if framed as symptom planning. Also clarify obstruction management (e.g., ureteral stent/nephrostomy) if present, since that affects urgent decisions.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Add a sentence establishing legal footing: that he has intact decision-making capacity, is making an informed refusal, and that honoring refusal and offering palliative/hospice is legally permissible; also that continued discussion without coercion is allowed. Example: “He is assessed to have decision-making capacity; informed refusal is documented, and symptom-focused care or continued counseling are both permissible within hospital policy and state law.”

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 2 risks being ethically/clinically indefensible because it can read as disregarding a clear refusal (“keep trying” due to daughter pressure) and ‘delay palliative’ without a principled trigger. Make the tension non-trivial by adding a credible reason to consider postponing hospice despite refusal—e.g., uncertainty about capacity due to new uremia, depression, or misunderstanding; or that he is open to a time-limited trial of evaluation if framed around maintaining independence. Alternatively, reframe Choice 2 as: “Request an ethics consult and schedule a structured goals-of-care meeting today while keeping the OR slot provisional,” rather than simply pushing curative planning against his stated refusal.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the ethical tension unavoidable rather than a simple informed-refusal scenario. Add facts that create a real dilemma: e.g., he demonstrates mixed understanding/misinformation about outcomes, expresses ambivalence, or there is concern for treatable depression, uncontrolled pain, or delirium affecting decision-making; OR he is willing to consider treatment if erectile function can be partially preserved or if recovery time is shorter, but fears loss of livelihood. Explicitly state what would be lost ethically in each option (e.g., accepting refusal risks preventable death; pushing further risks undermining a competent patient’s stated goals and damaging trust).

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Tighten the choices so their ethical meaning is robust and not dependent on wording like “keep trying.” Specify what ‘pursue further discussions and planning’ entails (e.g., scheduling staging scans and pre-op workup today, re-booking surgery, and involving family) and what limits apply (no coercion, no proceeding without consent). Alternatively, define Choice 2 as initiating a time-limited ‘decisional pause’ with psychiatry/palliative consult to assess capacity and treat potentially reversible factors before accepting refusal.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify decisional capacity and informedness. Right now most readers will interpret this as a capacitated, informed refusal with an obvious duty to honor it. Add concrete indicators that would make reasonable clinicians disagree: conflicting statements (“I don’t want surgery” but also “I’m terrified of dying”), recent major depressive symptoms, cognitive concerns, or misunderstanding of likely disease course; or a strong cultural/religious framework that complicates consent discussions. Also clarify whether he has received standardized counseling on alternatives (bladder-sparing chemoradiation, neobladder vs ileal conduit) so disagreement is about values, not missing information.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options so both are ethically defensible and costly. As written, Choice 1 aligns with standard respect for a competent refusal, while Choice 2 reads as paternalistic delay. To restore equipoise: (1) Make curative options plausibly aligned with his goals (e.g., bladder-sparing approach with shorter recovery, workplace accommodations, or high chance of meaningful survival) while still carrying significant burdens; AND (2) Make immediate palliative transition carry a clear moral cost (e.g., high likelihood of near-term obstructive complications, suffering, or potentially preventable death). Consider reframing Choice 2 as a time-limited structured re-discussion with capacity/depression screening and a second opinion, rather than open-ended ‘keep trying.’

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize value-laden phrasing that nudges toward either refusal or intervention. For example: (1) Replace the daughter’s quote “giving up too soon” with a more neutral request such as “please revisit the options with him.” (2) Balance the framing of treatment vs non-treatment: instead of “many patients regain function,” use neutral language like “radical cystectomy can offer disease control but involves major surgery with potential complications and functional changes.” (3) Replace “pulled into the hospital system” with neutral wording such as “he wishes to minimize hospital-based care.”

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Make both choices equally concrete, action-focused, and free of vague process words like “pursue discussions and planning.” Suggested rewrites (10–15 words each):
- Choice 1: “Honor his informed refusal and arrange outpatient palliative care and analgesia.”
- Choice 2: “Initiate staging and pre-op evaluation now, and schedule surgery pending reassessment.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make Choice 2 ethically/clinically defensible by introducing a credible reason the refusal may not yet be fully informed or stable (e.g., he was told the diagnosis today, appears in shock/tearful, expresses misconceptions like “surgery always kills you,” has untreated major depression, mild cognitive impairment, or opioid-intoxication; or language barrier/poor health literacy). Also strengthen the moral costs of Choice 1 (e.g., high likelihood of preventable painful decline soon, loss of a narrow potentially curative window, significant family conflict/clinician moral distress) so it’s not obviously the ‘right’ answer.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious middle-ground options. Explicitly rule out: (a) concurrent palliative care while continuing staging/education, (b) a time-limited ‘cooling-off’ period with scheduled follow-up in 48–72 hours, (c) ethics/psychiatry consult for decisional capacity today, (d) booking the OR slot while stating no surgery occurs without renewed consent, (e) obtaining minimal noninvasive staging that doesn’t ‘pull him into the system.’ Then rewrite the choices so they are truly mutually exclusive: e.g., Choice 1 = document informed refusal today, cancel pre-op workup/OR hold, shift fully to symptom-focused care; Choice 2 = initiate pre-op workup and staging now (labs/imaging/consults) to preserve the surgical window despite his stated refusal, with the intent to revisit consent later.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, a capacitated adult’s refusal of surgery/oncologic therapy is clearly protected by standard ethics/legal norms, making Choice 2 look like an impermissible override. To restore ‘gray zone,’ add a concrete, serious reason capacity or voluntariness is uncertain (acute urinary obstruction causing uremic encephalopathy, new severe pain requiring sedating meds, possible suicidal ideation/major depression, fluctuating confusion, coercion by employer/fear of job loss) and make the immediate decision about whether to proceed with time-sensitive staging/pre-op steps while capacity is assessed. Alternatively, redefine Choice 2 to be guideline-consistent: not planning treatment against his refusal, but insisting on a short, structured process to ensure informed refusal (teach-back, second opinion, mental health/capacity evaluation) before transitioning exclusively to palliative care.

data.vignette: A 56-year-old man is diagnosed today with muscle-invasive bladder cancer after weeks of hematuria and worsening urinary obstruction. He is admitted for pain and rising creatinine from hydronephrosis and has received IV opioids, with periods of drowsiness. Urology discusses radical cystectomy with urinary diversion and the possibility of systemic therapy or radiation depending on staging and findings. They also discuss non-definitive management focused on symptoms, which may avoid intensive treatment but can allow progression with recurrent bleeding, obstruction, and pain. He says he will not undergo “major cancer treatment,” declines staging scans, and asks only for medications so he can keep working and stay at home. At times he states he “doesn’t want to die,” but also says treatment is “pointless.” His daughter asks you to revisit the plan. The next surgical slot is next week, but pre-op testing and staging must start today or the slot is released and rebooking may take months. Hospital policy and state law permit either course in this situation.
data.choice_1: Document informed refusal, cancel pre-op workup and staging, and arrange hospice-oriented outpatient care.
data.choice_2: Start staging and pre-op evaluation today and keep surgery planning active pending reassessment.

choice_1.choice: Document informed refusal, cancel pre-op workup and staging, and arrange hospice-oriented outpatient care.

choice_2.choice: Start staging and pre-op evaluation today and keep surgery planning active pending reassessment.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause explicitly stating whether the patient is judged to have (or lack) decision-making capacity when he refuses staging/surgery (e.g., 'when fully awake off opioids, he demonstrates understanding and is assessed to have capacity').

Add a clause specifying concrete near-term harms of initiating staging/pre-op now (e.g., contrast CT with risk of worsening AKI/delirium while opioid-sedated), and a clause specifying concrete near-term harms of canceling workup (e.g., high risk of recurrent hemorrhage/obstructive renal failure and uncontrolled pain if definitive therapy is delayed for months).

Add a brief clause making the justice/resource-allocation stakes explicit (e.g., “another patient with aggressive cancer is waiting for that OR slot and will be bumped if it’s held,” or “today’s staging/pre-op slots are limited and reserving them prevents other patients from being evaluated”).

data.vignette: A 56-year-old man is diagnosed today with muscle-invasive bladder cancer after weeks of hematuria and worsening urinary obstruction. He is admitted for severe pain and rising creatinine from hydronephrosis. He has received IV opioids and is intermittently drowsy. When awake between doses, he can describe his diagnosis, options, and consequences, and he is assessed to have decision-making capacity. Urology recommends radical cystectomy with urinary diversion. Systemic therapy or radiation may be needed depending on staging. Staging CT may require IV contrast and could worsen his acute kidney injury or trigger delirium while sedated. Symptom-focused care could avoid intensive treatment, but delaying definitive therapy for months risks recurrent bleeding, obstructive renal failure, and uncontrolled pain with repeat admissions. He says he will not undergo major cancer treatment, declines staging scans, and requests only medications so he can keep working and stay at home. He is ambivalent about prognosis. His daughter asks you to revisit the plan. The next OR slot is next week. Pre-op testing and staging must start today or the slot is released. Another patient is waiting for that slot. Hospital policy and state law permit either course in this situation.

choice_1.choice: Document informed refusal, cancel staging and pre-op workup, and arrange hospice-oriented outpatient care.

choice_2.choice: Start staging and pre-op evaluation today and keep surgery planning active with reassessment.
